meanings.definition: To solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim)
meanings.sent1: She had to abjure her old ways and start anew.
meanings.sent2: He decided to abjure his allegiance to the rival gang.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to abjure the new catnip toy, preferring the old one instead.
meanings.sent4: The student abjured the easy path to success, choosing instead to work hard for his grades.
meanings.sent5: The knight abjured his loyalty to the king, swearing fealty to a new ruler.

meanings.sent1: The timid rabbit would abjure any loud noises, hiding in fear.
meanings.sent2: She would always abjure spicy food, preferring milder flavors.
meanings.sent3: The detective had to abjure the suspect's alibi, finding it too convenient.
meanings.sent4: The explorer abjured the treacherous mountain pass, opting for a safer route.
meanings.sent5: The child abjured the dark closet, afraid of what might be lurking inside.
